body_html:
This is not really the expected use for Dataset.from_generator() and as we discussed on Stack Overflow, you can use Dataset.map() if you need to capture a different iterator. However, I'm not quite sure what the use case is here... why don't you want to use the original iterator directly?

Use case: I have a dataset (d1, lengths) of variable length tensors (read from tfrecord files) and I want to produce from it another dataset d2 with slices of the tensors in d1.

I coincidentally fixed this in 3c00952.

I was bitten by the list vs tuple in Dataset.zip and took some to figure that out too - good job!

This is not really the expected use for Dataset.from_generator() and as we discussed on Stack Overflow, you can use Dataset.map() if you need to capture a different iterator. However, I'm not quite sure what the use case is here... why don't you want to use the original iterator directly?

Use case: I have a dataset (d1, lengths) of variable length tensors (read from tfrecord files) and I want to produce from it another dataset d2 with slices of the tensors in d1.

I coincidentally fixed this in 3c00952.

I was bitten by the list vs tuple in Dataset.zip and took some to figure that out too - good job!
body:
> This is not really the expected use for Dataset.from_generator() and as we discussed on Stack Overflow, you can use Dataset.map() if you need to capture a different iterator. However, I'm not quite sure what the use case is here... why don't you want to use the original iterator directly?

Use case: I have a dataset (d1, lengths) of variable length tensors (read from tfrecord files) and I want to produce from it another dataset d2 with _slices_ of the tensors in d1.

> I coincidentally fixed this in 3c00952.

I was bitten by the list vs tuple in Dataset.zip and took some to figure that out too - good job!
